Hi Ron,

It is, as Bob says, a pronunciation/spelling thing. The actual  
p=
ronunciation is /m/, so Namban. It is very difficult to pronounce /n/  
aft=
er the initial /n/, but some sources use that as the spelling. It  
is simi=
lar to the nengo Tenbun. Some sources give Tembun. I always use  
Namban an=
d Tenbun, but some other sources use the alternative spelling.

The carving=
 explanation sounds reasonable, but I think there is a fair  
degree of amb=
iguity over many of these terms. And, thanks for getting  
back on the kanj=
i stuff.

Gordon

On Jul 31, 2010, at 7:30 AM, Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Hi Go=
rdon -
>
> Yes, several explanations came in that cleared this up for me, s=
o  
> don't
> worry about trying to explain it again. Takes some explaining=
 but  
> also takes
> time to write it out! I admire you guys who have mast=
ered all of this
> language thing!!!
>
> Same thing about the two carving t=
echniques. As I thought, the one is
> carving away the ground to create low=
 relief, the other carving out  
> the
> design in what I've always heard w=
as sunken relief...if that makes  
> sense.
>
> Since you are involved with=
 the NTHK, let me ask this. The name Namban
> (Nanban, in modern terms, so =
I hear) is a general term. There are the
> sub-catagories for those fitting=
s. However, I've noticed that the  
> NBTHK,
> auction houses, dealers, etc=
. (I don't have any NTHK examples) do  
> not get so
> specific and call th=
ese things, "Namban." (Except perhaps for the most
> earliest examples?) Ca=
re to comment on this thinking for all to see???
> Interesting topic!
>
> S=
ee you in SF?
>
> Ron
